scenario_1.message: It’s great you’re putting in consistent effort. One thing that often helps is focusing on specific performance metrics—like your sprint times or goal-scoring stats—and sharing those with clubs or agents. That way, when a scout looks at your profile, they see concrete evidence of your progress rather than just the impression of your hard work.

I guess I could start keeping track, but what if the scouts still think I’m not good enough? They always look for players who have already been seen by big clubs. That’s my first thought—if they don’t see me, I’ll never get a chance.

It’s natural to feel that way, especially when past experiences set high expectations. However, many scouts actually appreciate players who show rapid improvement over time. Highlighting your recent growth could shift their perception more than a single prior exposure would.

scenario_2.message: Strength training effectiveness often depends on your current level and goals. If you’re already carrying a decent amount of load in your workouts, adding incremental increases—say 5% every few weeks—can keep you progressing without overloading.
But I’ve always thought that the bigger the weight, the better. My friends at the gym lift huge plates and they look like champions. If I don’t lift as much, I’ll be seen as weak.

That’s a common anchoring bias—basing your sense of progress on what you see first. Remember that proper form and progressive overload are more important than raw weight. Focusing on technique can actually make you stronger in the long run, which will help you maintain that status of physical strength you value.

metadata.demographics: South African man, 27 years old, born in Johannesburg. Plays semi-professional football, works part-time at a gym
metadata.beliefs: Sees sport as escape from poverty, values physical strength as status, believes teamwork teaches survival, dreams of being scouted abroad
